title: [BUG] can't run Evaluator(results).fit_runtime() with datatimes as strings
body:
**Describe the bug**

Executing the function Evaluator.fit_runtime() raises an error of operation:

run_times["fit_estimator_end_time"] - run_times["fit_estimator_start_time"]
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'str' and 'str'

I have a quick solution which may not be the better one wrote at "Additional context" of this Issue.

Thank you for you attention

**To Reproduce**

Using the Benchmarking, after run some predictions the Orchestrator will save the results in an object HDDResults so
we can evaluate the results using the Evaluator.
However, the Evaluator.fit_runtime() raises an error because it can't subtracts the values end_time and start_time which are
strings

```python
# Put the imports
# Set the path of your data and your results

datasets = make_datasets( path=DATA_PATH, dataset_cls=UEADataset, names=["BasicMotions"] )

tasks = [TSCTask(target="target") for _ in range(len(datasets))]

strategies = [
    TSCStrategy(MrSEQLClassifier(seql_mode='fs', symrep=['sax', 'sfa']), name="MrSEQL"),
    TSCStrategy(TemporalDictionaryEnsemble(min_window=6, n_jobs=-1), name="TDE")
]

results = HDDResults(path=RESULTS_PATH)

orchestrator = Orchestrator(
    datasets=datasets,
    tasks=tasks,
    strategies=strategies,
    cv=PresplitFilesCV(),
    results=results,
)
orchestrator.fit_predict(save_fitted_strategies=False, overwrite_predictions=False, verbose=True)

evaluator = Evaluator(results)

print(evaluator.fit_runtime())
```

**Expected behavior**
I expect the function showing a table with the run times, like bellow:

```python
                                fit_runtime  predict_runtime
strategy_name   dataset_name                               
 MrSEQL          BasicMotions    13.229782    1.936437
                 PenDigits       62.418973    1.117434
```
**Additional context**

inside file evaluation.py:
....
470        # change column dtypes to allow operations (+ , - , ...)
471        run_times["fit_estimator_start_time"] = [pd.Timestamp(s) for s in run_times["fit_estimator_start_time"]]
472        run_times["fit_estimator_end_time"] = [pd.Timestamp(s) for s in run_times["fit_estimator_end_time"]]
473        run_times["predict_estimator_start_time"] = [pd.Timestamp(s) for s in run_times["predict_estimator_start_time"]]
474        run_times["predict_estimator_end_time"] = [pd.Timestamp(s) for s in run_times["predict_estimator_end_time"]]
475        
476             # calculate run time difference
...

**Versions**
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
<details>

    python: 3.8.8 (default, Apr 13 2021, 15:08:03) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
executable: C:\Users\marci\anaconda3\python.exe
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.19041-SP0

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.0.1
   setuptools: 52.0.0.post20210125
      sklearn: 0.24.1
       sktime: 0.6.0
  statsmodels: 0.12.2
        numpy: 1.19.5
        scipy: 1.6.2
       Cython: 0.29.23
       pandas: 1.2.4
   matplotlib: 3.3.4
       joblib: 1.0.1
        numba: 0.53.1
     pmdarima: None
      tsfresh: None

</details>
